thread.title: Central Australian soil mapped with promising results
thread.title_full: Central Australian soil mapped with promising results

author: Katrina Beavan
title: Central Australian soil mapped with promising results
text:
Map: Ali Curung 0872 
Soil in arid parts of Central Australia has shown potential for horticultural development, a study has found. 
The Northern Territory Department of Environment and Natural Resources yesterday released a report mapping the soil west of Tennant Creek and further south in Ali Curung . 
Jason Hill, director of the Land Assessment Branch, said the soil would be suitable for a number of different crops. 
"Some of those are watermelons, hay, chia, grapes, mangoes, stone fruit, asparagus â€” a whole range of crops that are suited to that environment and suited to those soils," he said. 
"Essentially the sandy red earth was the target of our survey." 
Mr Hill said researchers looked at soils on pastoral and Aboriginal land. 
"Our information will direct [residents] to what we believe is the best soils," he said. 
"If a landholder wanted to look at development options, our maps will say 'Well, in this north-east part, the soils aren't particularly useful, but further to the west they are'. 
"We're about de-risking. There are lots of aspects to farming, and we try to provide at least some certainty that your soil resource is this and it's suitable for growing these crops. 
"It helps them grow the right crops on the right land [that is] sustainable in the long term and doesn't have an impact on the environment." Good groundwater supply 
Mr Hill said this was the first time information had been collected about the soil west of Tennant Creek. 
"There was some water resources drilling done in the early 80s which indicated a good groundwater supply," he said. 
"We're working together with water resources now to look at the soils and whether we've got that overlapping soil and water. 
"In Ali Curung, we've had some reconnaissance work done there in the past soil-wise, but this is the first time we've gone in intensively and mapped it in detail. 
"Our study coincides with the release of a new water allocation plan, so I think the two sets of information work really well together." 
Mr Hill said similar data was being finalised in other areas of the Northern Territory, including Wadeye, Gunn Point, Ti Tree, Dunmarra and Orange Creek. 
He said this year the department would look at surveying the Roper Valley and the western Barkly.
